questions.text: An autopsy was conducted on a male with a history of drowning. No water was found in his lungs, and he was labeled a case of dry drowning. What is the cause of death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Laryngospasm

Explanation:

Dry drowning occurs when water triggers a reflex laryngospasm, causing the airway to close. This prevents water from entering the lungs but also obstructs airflow, leading to hypoxia and death. This is the most accurate explanation for dry drowning.

Types of atypical drowning

Dry drowning

  • In dry drowning, water does not enter the lungs due to laryngeal spasms induced by small amounts of water entering the larynx.
  • Cause of death: Reflex cardiac arrest due to vasovagal stimulation.

Immersion syndrome (Cold water drowning)
  • It refers to syncope resulting from cardiac arrhythmias on sudden
  • contact with water that is at least 5°C lower than the body temperature.
  • Also called hydrocution or submersion inhibition.

Near drowning (post-immersion syndrome or secondary drowning)
  • Near drowning refers to survival beyond 24 hours after a submersion episode.
  • Death is caused by complications or sequelae like ARDS, pneumonia, sepsis, hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy, and DIC.

Asphyxia (Option A): Asphyxia is a general term for oxygen deprivation leading to death, it is not the direct mechanism in dry drowning. The absence of water in the lungs suggests a different mechanism.

Vagal inhibition (Option B): Vagal inhibition can lead to sudden death due to overactivation of the vagus nerve, but it is not the primary cause in cases of dry drowning.

Ventricular fibrillation (Option D): Ventricular fibrillation is not typically associated with dry drowning. It is more likely in cases of electrocution or cardiac conditions.

questions.text: A girl was found deceased in a lake, and her body was retrieved. Which of the following is false regarding ante-mortem drowning?

choices.text: No mud and vegetation in the respiratory tract

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) No mud and vegetation in the respiratory tract

Explanation:

  • In ante-mortem drowning, mud, vegetation, or other debris from the drowning medium may be aspirated into the respiratory tract during the victim’s struggle to breathe.
  • The presence of these elements can confirm ante-mortem drowning.

Signs of Antemortem Drowning:

  • External Signs: Foam at the mouth/nose, Washerwoman skin, Cyanosis.
  • Internal Signs: Lungs: Over-distended, heavy, and waterlogged, Mucus: Sticky mucus in airways due to fluid inhalation.
  • Diatoms: Microscopic algae in internal organs (bone marrow), indicating water inhalation.
  • Paltauf’s spots: Subpleural hemorrhages caused by lung over-expansion.

Water in the stomach (Option A): In cases of ante-mortem drowning, water may be swallowed and found in the stomach as a result of reflexive actions during the drowning process.

Froth on nose and mouth (Option B): Froth is a characteristic feature of ante-mortem drowning, caused by the mixing of water, air, and mucus during respiratory efforts.

Cadaveric spasm in hand muscle (Option D): Cadaveric spasm, particularly in the hand muscles (e.g., tightly holding grass or weeds), is often seen in drowning cases as a sign of intense physical and emotional struggle before death.

Correct Answer B - Burking

Burking is a type of homicide caused by smothering and traumatic asphyxia.

  • In this method, the attacker kneels or sits on the chest of the victim and closes the victim's mouth and nose with his or her hands.
  • Traumatic asphyxia occurs due to respiratory arrest due to mechanical fixation of the chest.
  • This prevents normal respiratory movements from happening.

There are a few types of homicide that involve similar methods or characteristics to burking.

  • Suffocation: Suffocation involves depriving a person of oxygen by covering their airways, often by using a hand, pillow, plastic bag, or other objects.
  • Smothering: Smothering is a type of suffocation where the perpetrator covers the victim's nose and mouth, blocking their ability to breathe.
  • Strangulation: Although not exactly the same as burking, strangulation involves applying pressure to the neck, either manually or using a ligature
  • Choking: Choking occurs when an object or material obstructs the airway, preventing the person from breathing properly.

Mugging (Option A): is a method of strangulation caused by holding the neck of the victim in the bend of the elbow. The attacker usually attacks from behind.

Garrotting (Option C): is a method of strangulation caused by a ligature being thrown around the neck and quickly tightening it.

Bansdola (Option D): is a method of strangulation that uses two bamboo sticks.

questions.text: What is this finding suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Antemortem Drowning features include the presence of froth in the mouth and nostrils, water in the lungs, hyperinflated lungs, and diatoms in internal organs.These findings indicate that the individual was alive at the time of submersion and inhaled water, leading to drowning.

 

Signs of Antemortem Drowning:

  • External Signs: Foam at the mouth/nose, Washerwoman skin, Cyanosis.
  • Internal Signs: Lungs: Over-distended, heavy, and waterlogged, Mucus: Sticky mucus in airways due to fluid inhalation.
  • Diatoms: Microscopic algae in internal organs (bone marrow), indicating water inhalation.
  • Paltauf’s spots: Subpleural hemorrhages caused by lung over-expansion.

Drowning after organophosphate poisoning (Option A):
Incorrect because organophosphates may cause respiratory depression or paralysis, but they do not cause typical signs like frothy fluid due to struggle during drowning.

Drowning after arsenic poisoning (Option C):
Incorrect because arsenic causes gastrointestinal symptoms and circulatory collapse but does not produce the classic drowning features like froth or emphysema aquosum.

None of the above (Option D):
Incorrect because antemortem drowning is the correct diagnosis based on classic forensic findings.

questions.text:
Which of the following is seen in freshwater drowning?

A. Haemodilution

B. Hypokalemia

C. Hyponatremia

D. Arrhythmia
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) A, C & D

Explanation:

Features

Freshwater Drowning

Seawater Drowning

Pathophysiology
  • Haemodilution (Statement A): Inhalation increases blood volume by 50%, causing anemia, hemolysis, and myocardial hypoxia.
  • Electrolyte Changes: Marked hyponatremia (Statement C) and hyperkalemia (Statement B ruled out); calcium decrease leads to arrhythmias. (Statement D)
  • Surfactant Dysfunction: Freshwater denatures the surfactant which causes alveolar collapse and pulmonary oedema.
  • Cardiac Load: Increased pulmonary oedema and electrolyte imbalances decrease cardiac output and cause hypotension.
  • Haemoconcentration: High salinity (≥3% NaCl) draws water into the lungs, causing severe pulmonary oedema and elevated plasma sodium.
  • Electrolyte Changes: Increased blood viscosity leads to bradycardia and myocardial failure; altered potassium and sodium levels(hypernatremia)
  • Red Cell Changes: Crenation of red blood cells impairs oxygen transport.
  • Myocardial Anoxia: Asphyxia from pulmonary oedema and cardiac stress results in hypoxia and potential arrest.

Lung characteristics
  • Size: Ballooned but light; pale pink colour; emphysematous consistency.
  • Shape after Removal: Retained, no collapse; crepitus with little froth and no fluid.
  • Size: Ballooned and heavy; purplish or bluish colour; soft, jelly-like consistency.
  • Shape after Removal: Flattened; no crepitus; copious fluid and froth.

Fatal period
  • Death typically occurs within 4-5 minutes
  • Death may take 8-10 minutes.

questions.text: You are posted as an intern in casualty when an MLC (Medico-Legal Case) is brought by the police. The deceased has the following appearance and was declared brought dead. What is the likely cause of death before sending the body for postmortem?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Drowning

Explanation:

  • The image is suggestive of Drowning. Key findings in drowning cases are as follows;

Signs of Antemortem Drowning:

  • External Signs: Foam at the mouth/nose, Washerwoman skin, Cyanosis.
  • Internal Signs:
    • Lungs: Over-distended, heavy, and waterlogged,
    • Mucus: Sticky mucus in airways due to fluid inhalation.
  • Diatoms: Microscopic algae in internal organs (bone marrow), indicating water inhalation.
  • Paltauf’s spots: Subpleural hemorrhages caused by lung over-expansion.

Incorrect Options:

Hanging (Option B): Hanging typically shows signs like:

  • Ligature marks on the neck, running obliquely and above the thyroid cartilage.
  • Petechial hemorrhages in the conjunctiva.
  • Absence of water-related findings like froth or washerwoman's hands.

Strangulation (Option C): Strangulation presents with:

  • Horizontal ligature marks.
  • Extensive neck bruising and petechiae.
  • No water-related findings.


Traumatic asphyxia (Option D): Traumatic asphyxia is caused by severe compression of the chest, leading to cyanosis and petechial hemorrhages, without water-related findings.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man was found dead at home and brought to the mortuary by the police. Upon examination, certain findings were noted. What is the likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Strangulation by ligature

Explanation:

  • Strangulation by ligature is typically characterized by:
    • Horizontal ligature marks on the neck, often at or above the level of the thyroid cartilage.
    • Deep bruising around the neck area, often due to the tight ligature.
    • Petechial hemorrhages in the eyes, face, and skin above the ligature mark.
    • Absence of other signs of hanging, such as the upward traction on the neck.
    • No evidence of a fall or suspension, which distinguishes it from hanging.

Causes of Death in Ligature Strangulation:

  1. Asphyxia
  2. Cerebral anoxia
  3. Vagal inhibition
  4. Cervical Vertebrae Fracture

Postmortem Findings:

1. External Examination:

Finding

Description

Face
  • Congested, swollen, and cyanosed.
  • Tardieu's spots (petechiae) on the forehead, temples, eyelids, and conjunctiva.
  • Prominent eyes with congested conjunctiva, dilated pupils, and possible subconjunctival haemorrhages.
  • Cyanosis of lips, fingernails, and earlobes.
  • Postmortem staining above the ligature.
  • Swollen, dark-coloured, protruding tongue, possibly bitten.
  • Bloodstained frothy fluid and mucus in mouth and nostrils.

Neck
  • Ligature mark ('furrow'): well-defined groove, typically the same width as the ligature, often horizontal.
  • More prominent on the front and sides of the neck.
  • Red base with congested or ecchymosed margins; imprint pattern may be present.
  • Can be indistinct if the ligature is soft; it may appear as a deep groove with a narrow cord ('cheese cutter method').
  • May show an oblique appearance if the victim was dragged post-strangulation.

Other Body Parts
  • Deep, prominent postmortem staining.
  • Involuntary discharge of urine and faecal matter; less common seminal ejaculation.
  • Clenched hands; possible genital turgidity.
  • Possible abrasions, fingernail marks, and contusions on face, and arms, indicating struggle.
  • Horizontal, irregular abrasions on the neck may indicate attempts to remove ligature.

2. Internal Examination:

  • On dissection- Contusion and haemorrhage- of tissue, muscles of the neck, tonsils and glands.
  • Fracture of the thyroid cartilage is commonly seen.
  • Fracture of the hyoid bone is not very common as it is usually at or below the level of the thyroid.

Incorrect Options:

Hanging (Option B): Hanging is characterized by:

  • Oblique ligature marks typically at or below the thyroid cartilage.
  • Signs of suspension or a fall from height.
  • Petechial hemorrhages and tongue protrusion.
  • Possible fractures of the cervical spine or hyoid bone.
    Hanging marks are different in appearance from those caused by strangulation with a ligature.

 

Throttling (Option C): Throttling involves manual strangulation and is characterized by:

  • Irregular ligature marks or fingerprints on the neck.
  • Bruising around the neck due to the pressure applied by hands.
  • No horizontal ligature marks like in strangulation by a ligature.

 

Drowning (Option D): Drowning typically shows:

  • Water in the lungs and froth at the mouth.
  • Washerwoman’s hands and mud in the respiratory tract.
  • Absence of ligature marks or any other signs of manual strangulation.

questions.text: A person was found dead in a swimming pool. On autopsy, his stomach and lungs were filled with water, and there was evidence of mucoid froth at the nose and mouth. What is the most likely mode of death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Wet drowning

Explanation:

  • Wet drowning occurs when water enters the airways and lungs during the drowning process, leading to asphyxia. Autopsy findings typically show water in the lungs and stomach, and mucoid froth at the nose and mouth is a classical sign due to mixing of water, air, and surfactant.
  • In wet drowning, inhaled water reaches the alveoli, causing washout of surfactant, alveolar collapse, and hypoxemia. It accounts for the majority of drowning deaths (about 90%). The frothy fluid seen at the mouth and nostrils is often copious and persistent, even after wiping. The stomach may also contain swallowed water.
  • Common causes include accidental submersion, suicidal drowning, and occasionally homicidal drowning.

Specific signs of antemortem drowning

  • Fine white froth at mouth & nostrils — increases on chest compression

  • Overdistended (“ballooned”) lungs — heavy, edematous, exuding watery froth on section

  • Paltauf’s hemorrhages — subpleural bluish-red patches due to rupture of alveolar septa

  • Emphysema aquosum — overinflated, water-filled lungs without putrefactive gases

  • Diatoms in organs (bone marrow, brain) — confirms aspiration of water before death

  • Water in the stomach & small intestine — due to swallowing during the struggle

  • Washerwoman’s hands/feet — wrinkling of skin from immersion (early in both antemortem & postmortem, but more marked in prolonged immersion)

  • Cutis anserina (gooseflesh) — due to contraction of arrector pili muscles

  • Cadaveric spasm: Surest sign of antemortem drowning

Feature

Wet drowning

Dry drowning

Mechanism

Aspiration of water into the lungs

Reflex laryngospasm → asphyxia, minimal/no water in lungs

Froth

Profuse, fine, persistent

Minimal or absent

Lungs

Heavy, water-logged, edematous

Normal or slightly edematous

Stomach contents

Water usually present

Usually absent

Proportion

Most cases (~75–80%)

Fewer cases (~10–20%)

Cause of death

Asphyxia + hemodilution + electrolyte disturbance

Asphyxia due to laryngospasm

Incorrect Options:

Dry drowning (Option A): Occurs due to laryngeal spasm preventing water entry into the lungs; lungs remain dry.

Near drowning (Option C): Refers to survival after submersion for at least 24 hours before death; not applicable here.

Cardiac arrest (Option D): This is the terminal event in many deaths, but it is not the specific mode of death in this case.
